channel.description: Recent content in longitudinal-data on CatBoItAEm

item.title: Confidence intervals for longitudinal models in R
item.description: # Libraries necessary for this plot library(lme4) ## Lade nötiges Paket: Matrix library(emmeans) library(ggplot2) # Data and regression model data(sleepstudy) mod <- lmer(Reaction ~ Days + (1|Subject), data=sleepstudy) gr <- ref_grid(mod, cov.keep= c("Days")) emm <- emmeans(gr, spec= c('Days'), level= 0.95) # Plot ggplot(data = sleepstudy, mapping = aes(x = Days, y = Reaction, col = Subject)) + geom_line() + geom_line(data = data.frame(emm), mapping = aes(y = emmean, col = NULL)) + geom_ribbon(data = data.

item.title: Spaghetti plot in SAS
item.description: With the following code, you can generate a spaghetti plot in SAS. This is useful for showing longitudinal data of different group or individual patients. The example plot is grouped by several different variables: group=: individual lines, e.g. data of one individual patients, grouplc=: line colours, e.g. treatment group, and grouplp=: line pattern, e.g. belonging to the per-protocol set or not. It is generated by the SAS procedure proc sgplot using the code below:
